I was asked by a journal to write about 5000 words on "Will machines change mathematics?". I've just finished version 1 and attach it below; does anyone here have any comments about the paper? I'll upload version 2 to ArXiv. Experts in ML might want to cast their eyes over "2.1: introduction to neural networks" (which is very much at the boundary of my understanding) and the last section 4 on large language models (ditto).

BAMS_Buzzard.pdf

Regarding section 2.1, I think I would add that the neural networks are trained with gradient descent methods, and that as a result the problem they are solving is not just function interpolation but "(implicitly) regularized function interpolation". This explains why one might hope for the resulting functions defined on high-dimensional spaces by a handful of points to generalize at all. A reference I like for this sort of result is https://arxiv.org/pdf/2101.12176.pdf but https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_tangent_kernel might be of higher theoretical value.
(This also resonates with your discussion on image classification vs. rank from coefficients vs. rank from Weierstrass)
I just came across the following, which seems relevant: https://arxiv.org/abs/2304.12602
I'm very proud to say that I spotted a mistake in the discussion of the Birch and Swinnerton-Dyers conjecture. I guess this makes me a better number-theorist than Kevin :muscle:
Ok, the typo is: every ggg in this paragraph should be rrr.
First paragraph Section 2.2: saying the authors are knot theorist isn't fair to their expertise range. Write "low dimensional topologists" would already be a lot better.

Page 5, I'm not sure the first sentence of second paragraph (With this in mind...) is accurate, you should double-check. My understanding is they searched for any correlations among all those invariants.
In Section 3.1, you should probably mention ATP have a huge role in software verification, otherwise people won't understand why they exist.

You wrote "However typically now the logic and theory are sufficiently rich that the system can encompass all or most of modern mathematics." but this is also true for first order logic. I know what you mean but your average reader won't and will be puzzled.
Bottom of Page 7, you want to describe polyrith but wrote "linear algebra". Or are you mixing linarith and polyrith? And Rob will probably insist that you should cite his student.
On Page 9: "This idea is unfortunately still science fiction right now", do you try to initiate a polemic on purpose? Most people probably think this is not unfortunate that we can keep our jobs.
Footnote 3 is a bit weird in singling out 2 courses among a lot of them.
Page 2: "which which" --> "with which"?
We had a talk yesterday by Gukov which included https://arxiv.org/pdf/2304.09304
Page 8: "Avigad let a team" --> "led"
Calling the IMO Grand Challenge "still at least a few years away" seems like speculation?
Page 1: Nitpick: The proofs of the PNT by de la Vallee Poussin and Hadamard were both published in 1896, so not quite 20th Century...
"Will machines change mathematics?" also seems like speculation... :wink:

Here are some comments about the low-dimensional topology part (maybe you should check with someone else in the Field that these are not just my opinions).

  • Firstly, the real issue is not "discrete" versus "continuous" invariants but rather relations between "Quantum" invariants (such as the Jones polynomial) and "Algebraic/Geometric topology" invariants (homology, Alexander polynomial, Gromov/Thurston norms). There is also a third class of invariants - those from Gauge theory. While the hyperbolic volume is indeed continuous, it would be just as useful to relate the Jones polynomial to say the Gromov/Thurston norm (which is discrete).
  • This is important because the Quantum invariants are the most powerful in the sense of being able to distinguish knots, but the least geometric/topological so are often weak in terms of proving theorems.
  • In a sense the result does not quite do this, since the Reidemeister signature is an Algebraic/Geometric topology invariant.

So some data for the point I made: the paper https://www.jstor.org/stable/2160250 by Culler and Shalen in Proc AMS relates a discrete invariant - the betti number, with the hyperbolic volume (a continuous invariant). This is from the 1990s - certainly a non-trivial paper by leading topologists, but just that such results have been proved.
And another relating volume to discrete stuff: https://escholarship.org/uc/item/6hs2x341

Very nice text @Kevin Buzzard ! I have only minor/typographical comments:

  • page 2: Zr×T\mathbb{Z}^r\times TZr×T with TTT a finite abelian group
  • page 2: was that if if ppp is prime and NpN_pNp​...
  • page 2: I undestand when you say that the currency is the theorem but you have just quoted three outstanding mathematicians for their conjectures. Also, Geordie's paper is a lot about using IA to make conjectures, so probably the currency is something more like the insight, or the vision, or the understanding... ?
  • page 3: when you quote the LMFDB, you write L-function (twice), in the Intro you wrote LLL-function (with LLL in math font).
  • page 3, the line below: an elliptic curve of over the rationals; in the same line, "the subscripts are have to do...".
  • Beginning of 2.3: In the sentence "Given two elements of the symmetric group...two invariants", do you want to add "one can associate to them" or to replace the "Given two elements" by "To two elements.."?
  • page 7: "comprehensible to a human in finite time" is funny, probably a bit pleonastic: few mortals should be capable to comprehend something in an infinite amount of time :smile:
  • On pages 7/8, you cite Rob Lewis, Scott Morrison and Georges Gonthier by Name Surname, while Paulson, Blanchette and Avigad only by Surname.
  • Page 8, you lack the diacritics on Erdős
  • On three occurrences in the text and one in a footnote you use "I" (Second paragraph of 5, Third of page 9, final sentence of 2.2; and foonote 3), all the other times you say "we". You even refer to yourself as "the author" at the end of Section 4.
  • Personal note: I very much agree with your final sentence!
Thanks everyone for the comments! I'll take them into account with the next revision in a couple of weeks
Page 8: "Having demonstrated that ITPs could be used check computer-assisted proofs" is missing "to".
